channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: A Vow of Silence, a Cabin in the Woods, a Terrible Wildfire
item.description: If anyone could outsmart a wildfire, it would seem to be Tad Jones, who lived for decades in a California forest, more a friend of nature than of man.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Fuller and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs

item.title: Federal Government Relaxes Rules on Feeding Low-Income Students
item.description: Under pressure from Congress, the Agriculture Department agreed to extend special rules making it easier for schools to provide subsidized meals, but only through December.
item.dc:creator: Kate Taylor
item.media:description: When schools closed their doors in March, the Agriculture Department issued waivers allowing districts to give a free meal to any child 18 or younger.

item.title: Liberty Will Investigate University’s Operations Under Jerry Falwell Jr.
item.description: The board of trustees said an independent forensic firm would look into all facets of Liberty’s operations, including “financial, real estate and legal matters,” while Mr. Falwell was president.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Graham
item.media:description: Jerry Falwell Jr., who had served as Liberty’s president and chancellor since 2007, resigned last week in the wake of a sex scandal.

item.title: Snapped Poles, Shredded Roofs: A Long Road to Recovery After Laura
item.description: Hurricane Laura ravaged southwestern Louisiana, leaving weary residents to assess the toll and map a way forward. Some communities may be four weeks away from even getting power back.
item.dc:creator: Rick Rojas
item.media:credit: William Widmer for The New York Times
item.media:description: The entire roof of a Motel 6 was ripped off as Hurricane Laura blew through Lake Charles, La., on Thursday. Buildings, trees and utility poles all over the city were damaged.

item.title: Biden Lashes Back at Trump
item.description: The president heads to Kenosha, despite worries of further unrest: This is your politics tip sheet.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello

item.title: America’s Death Gap
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: A memorial in Washington last week for those who died from the coronavirus.

item.title: Covid-19 News: Live Updates
item.description: These efforts are motivated, at least in part, by the same idea: Exceptional times demand exceptional actions.

item.title: ‘I Am Stuck Until That Border Opens’: Marooned in Paradise
item.description: This geographically isolated community in Washington State has avoided the coronavirus, but at a considerable cost.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Fremson
item.media:description: To reach the rest of the United States from Point Roberts, Wash., requires two international border crossings with a 24-mile drive in between.

item.title: The State Fair Is Canceled. Deep-Fried Oreos Are Not.
item.description: Food vendors and their devoted fans are going to great lengths, from drive-throughs to phone apps, to keep the corn dogs and chickens-on-a-stick flowing.
item.dc:creator: Marissa Conrad
item.media:credit: Jenn Ackerman for The New York Times

item.title: Help! What Are the Best Precautions When Traveling by Car?
item.description: Our columnist answers your coronavirus-related questions about health and safety on road trips.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Firshein

item.title: As Guns Get Drawn at Protest Sites, Demonstrators Fear a Volatile New Phase
item.description: As right-wing groups increasingly move to confront unrest in cities, demonstrators are taking drastic steps in assessing how to keep themselves safe.
item.dc:creator: Mike Baker, Julie Bosman and Richard A. Oppel Jr.
item.media:credit: Mason Trinca for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protestors gathered in Portland, Ore., as officers watched from patrol vehicles on Sunday. In recent weeks, long-time activists have grown jittery about revving vehicles and unfamiliar faces in the crowds.

item.title: What We Learned From the R.N.C.
item.description: In a live discussion, Times national reporters talked about the themes at the Republican convention and the strategies in play to help President Trump get re-elected.
item.media:description: At the convention, President Trump and other speakers sought to soften his image in an appeal to swing voters.

item.title: Why Alyssa Cole Put Romance Aside and Wrote a Thriller About Gentrification
item.description: “I wanted the characters to be more morally gray, where I could explore some darker areas,” the novelist said of her new book, “When No One Is Watching.”
item.dc:creator: Concepción de León
item.category: When No One Is Watching: A Thriller (Book)

item.title: These Scientists Are Giving Themselves D.I.Y. Coronavirus Vaccines
item.description: Impatient for a coronavirus vaccine, dozens of scientists around the world are giving themselves — and sometimes, friends and family — their own unproven versions.
item.dc:creator: Heather Murphy
item.media:credit: Kayana Szymczak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Preston Estep, chief scientist and co-founder of RaDVaC, administering an eighth iteration of his vaccine on August 19.

item.title: Los Angeles Sheriff’s Deputies Fatally Shoot a Black Man They Say Had a Gun
item.description: The man, who had been stopped while riding a bicycle, was shot several times after a fight broke out, the Sheriff’s Department said.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor and Azi Paybarah
item.media:credit: Andrew Cullen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Police officers at the site where a crowd gathered in protest after a Black man was shot by Los Angeles County sheriffs’ deputies late Monday.

item.title: A Long History of Language That Incites and Demonizes
item.description: President Trump has employed provocative and sometimes incendiary words and images to focus attention on demonstrations and away from the human and economic costs of the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:description: President Trump’s approach to a summer of protests has been consistent with a career of combative politics that play to racial animosities.

item.title: A Teacher and Congresswoman Confronts School Reopenings
item.description: Representative Jahana Hayes, a former National Teacher of the Year, says that she has many concerns — and that parents need to make their voices heard.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein
item.media:credit: Jessica Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Jahana Hayes, a former teacher, at Yale Law School last year.

item.title: Trump Fans Strife as Unrest Roils the U.S.
item.description: The president plans to visit to Kenosha, Wis., on Tuesday, unwelcome by officials in a state pivotal to the election, to condemn what he calls “left-wing mobs.”
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker and Maggie Haberman
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: From his time as a celebrity real estate developer, President Trump has never been a conciliator, and has long gravitated toward conflict and sought to escalate it.

item.title: House Panel to Subpoena DeJoy Over Mail Delays and Trump Communications
item.description: The chairwoman of the House Oversight Committee said the postmaster general had withheld requested documents, telling her panel his verbal testimony should suffice.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater
item.category: House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Postmaster General Louis DeJoy has instituted changes that have resulted in confusion and coincided with a slowdown in delivery times and an effort by the president to attack mail-in voting.

item.title: Joe Ruby, a Creator of ‘Scooby-Doo,’ Is Dead at 87
item.description: Charged with creating an animated mystery series, Mr. Ruby and his writing partner, Ken Spears, came up with a show that endures more than 50 years later.
item.dc:creator: Penelope Green
item.media:description: The cast of “Scooby-Doo, Where Are You!” included a ragtag quartet of teenage sleuths and a Great Dane said to be modeled on Bob Hope.

item.title: Hamas and Israel Agree to Ease Hostilities Amid Coronavirus
item.description: With the coronavirus spreading fast in Gaza, the sides agreed to stop bombarding each other, and Israel said it would resume fuel supplies. A cash infusion from Qatar helped seal the deal.
item.dc:creator: David M. Halbfinger and Adam Rasgon
item.media:description: Palestinian police officers guarded streets in Gaza City last week as part of a 48-hour lockdown imposed to curb the spread of the coronavirus.

item.title: E.P.A. Relaxes Rules Limiting Toxic Waste From Coal Plants
item.description: The agency weakened Obama-era rules meant to keep metals and other pollution out of rivers and streams, saving industry tens of millions of dollars.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: The new rule scaled back the types of wastewater treatment technologies that utilities must install.

item.title: TikTok Deal Faces Complications as U.S. and China Ratchet Up Tit-for-Tat
item.description: China’s new export rules, which could delay or scuttle a sale of TikTok, have further turned giant companies into pawns in a geopolitical struggle.
item.dc:creator: Mike Isaac and Ana Swanson

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: Campus outbreaks are beginning to infect surrounding communities.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe and Lara Takenaga

item.title: In Speech, Biden Confronts Trump on Safety: 'He Can't Stop the Violence'
item.description: In a blistering speech, Joe Biden charged that crises “have kept multiplying” under President Trump’s watch. It was an effort to refocus the spotlight on the incumbent after a week of Republican attacks.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck

item.title: At the W.N.B.A., the Fight for Racial Justice Goes Way Back
item.description: “It’s like basketball: Preparation shows, and we’ve been prepared for this moment,” says New York Liberty guard Layshia Clarendon.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra E. Petri
item.media:description: The Washington Mystics wore white T-shirts that spelled out Jacob Blake on the front and featured illustrations of seven bullet holes on the back. The team was protesting the police shooting of a Black man in Kenosha, Wis., during the W.N.B.A. postponement announcement on Wednesday at Feld Entertainment Center in Palmetto, Fla.

item.title: Ron Jeremy Is Newly Charged With Sexually Assaulting 13 More Women
item.description: The new charges brought by the Los Angeles County District Attorney’s office against the pornographic film star bring the total number of alleged victims to 17.
item.dc:creator: Julia Jacobs
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Robert Gauthier/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: The actor Ron Jeremy, appearing for his arraignment in Los Angeles in June. On Monday he was charged with additional counts of sexual assault.

item.title: Court Denies Flynn’s Bid to End Case and Renews Fight Over McGahn Subpoena
item.description: Two cases touching on the Trump-Russia investigation are dividing the Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Michael T. Flynn twice pleaded guilty to lying to the F.B.I.

item.title: The wheels come off the school bus industry
item.description: And students in Britain and New Jersey are facing a particularly uncertain start to the year.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg and Adam Pasick
item.media:credit: Lauren Lancaster for The New York Times
item.media:description: Glenn Every said the school bus company he owns has lost $750,000 because of the pandemic.

item.title: Twitter flags a video shared by Steve Scalise that manipulated Ady Barkan’s interview with Biden.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens and Thomas Kaplan
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Steve Scalise released a video that doctored the words of the activist Ady Barkan, center, in an interview with Joseph R. Biden Jr.

item.title: China's Exports Are Surging Despite Tariffs and Coronavirus
item.description: Chinese companies account for a greater share of goods sold abroad, showing their tremendous strength despite mounting challenges.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:credit: Andrea Verdelli for The New York Times
item.media:description: Workers assembling saunas at Hongyuan Furniture, a manufacturer in Guangzhou, China.

item.title: In the Massachusetts Senate primary, Markey has outflanked Kennedy by running as a bold insurgent.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Martin
item.media:description: Senator Edward J. Markey debated Representative Joseph P. Kennedy III earlier this month. The two will face off in a Senate primary tomorrow.

item.title: Coronavirus in California: The State's Plan for Reopening
item.description: Monday: Here’s what you need to know about California’s second big reopening plan. Also: Eviction legislation; and Chadwick Boseman.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan
item.media:description: Corinne Lam and her husband, Anthony Lam, carried a chair in from an outside area as they prepared to receive clients back inside their salon Friday in San Diego.

item.title: Facing national unrest, Biden confronts both a challenge and an opportunity.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nagourney and Shane Goldmacher
item.media:description: Joe Biden accepted the Democratic nomination for president at the Chase Center in Wilmington, Del.

item.title: The Portland shooting amplified tensions in the presidential race.
item.description: A fatal shooting after clashes in Portland came on the heels of the shooting deaths of two people during confrontations in Kenosha, Wis., earlier in the week.
item.dc:creator: Mike Baker, Thomas Kaplan and Shane Goldmacher
item.media:credit: Mason Trinca for The New York Times
item.media:description: A man affiliated with a right-wing group was shot and killed on Saturday in Portland, Ore., where supporters of President Trump traveled in a caravan through the downtown area and clashed with protesters.

item.title: An advocacy group’s ‘Unbossed Women’s Agenda’ would help Black domestic workers.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Grullón Paz

item.title: A shift on election briefings to Congress could create an information gap for voters.
item.description: The elimination of in-person election security briefings to Congress could leave the public with a diminished understanding of the threats facing the election as it enters a critical phase.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Gabriella Demczuk for The New York Times
item.media:description: John Ratcliffe, the director of national intelligence, said he wanted to stop “a pandemic of information being leaked out of the intelligence community.”
